question: 7 (b)
sols_html:
Our line has a y-intercept when \(x = 0\). Plugging this into our equation of the line, we get

\[\begin{aligned} y = m(0) - m + 1 = -m + 1.\end{aligned}\]

So our y-intercept is \((0, -m + 1)\).

Similarly, our x-intercept occurs when \(y = 0\). Setting our equation equal to zero and solving for \(x\), we get

\[\begin{aligned} 0 = mx - m + 1\end{aligned}\]

We see that if m=0, then there is no x-intercept (the line is horizontal). Otherwise

\[\begin{aligned} x = \frac{m-1}{m}\end{aligned}\]

and our x-intercept is \(\left(\frac{m-1}{m} ,0\right)\).
